Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Gas Chromatograph-Mass Spectrometer (GCMS) for Citizen- and Student-Driven Inquiry in Urban District of Columbia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The MRI instrumentation seeks to engage neighborhoods and schools in an urban setting (Washington DC) to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups and low-income students in understanding environmental issues that affect their quality of life, health and environmental justice. A combination of research and educational tasks will advance both the understanding of urban environmental factors and inquiry based STEM education. Partnerships will be sought in neighborhoods where residents are concerned about their ambient air quality, with students informing them specifically for volatile organic compounds (VOCs), many of which are known toxins. Characterizing spatial and temporal variations of atmospheric VOCs will complement prior studies of particulate matter and metals, help inform studies of health disparities, and allow direct comparisons with other urban areas.

The central instrument is a gas chromatograph / mass spectrometer (GCMS) to be housed in a new science building at Trinity Washington University, a Minority Serving Institution in Washington, D.C. with a traditional liberal arts college curriculum for women. Encouragement of underepresented minorities to actively participate in STEM fields serves, demographically, the national interst.


Trinity Washington University is a non-Ph.D. granting institution as defined in Section IV of the NSF MRI solicitation

POR.DRECONTENT:
What kinds of chemicals and pollutants are in the air I breathe? What are the concentrations? With this grant and the purchase of a gas chromatograph mass spectrometer (GCMS), community partners and undergraduate students at Trinity Washington University, an all-women?s liberal arts college and minority-serving institution in Washington, DC, now have the capacity to answer these questions.

  • Community partners living near two concrete plants and continuous construction have been concerned about their exposure to dust and soot, specifically about fine particulate (PM2.5) that can penetrate deep into the lungs and contribute to respiratory and cardiovascular disease. Continuous, real-time PM monitoring in their neighborhood has revealed the importance of looking beyond one-hour or 24-hour average levels. Instead, to better describe their experiences, monitoring needs to capture spikes PM2.5, high levels that last for a few minutes.
  • Trinity undergraduates conceived and designed their own projects to identify chemicals in air emitted from air fresheners they use in their homes / cars and from hair care products. Chemicals emitted from hair care products include substances that were not listed on the ingredients and substances that are known carcinogens. Student projects also characterized the chemicals in-cabin air during a commute in Washington, DC and the air in an underground parking garage.

Chemical analysis using the GCMS is enhancing teaching Trinity. Students who benefit include visiting high school students and, since at least four semesters of Chemistry are required for them, all science majors at Trinity.

  • What is in our water? Approximately 100 students from a public charter high school in DC visited Trinity, toured the campus, and participated in five hands-on experiments, assisted by Trinity undergraduates.
  • How can we remove disinfection byproducts from water? Disinfection byproducts are chemicals in tap water that come from the process of killing harmful bacteria by chlorination. Introductory chemistry (CHEM111) students (~30 per year) identify what disinfection byproducts are in DC tap water, and then in an open-ended exercise, devise and test ways of removing those chemicals from the water.
  • What did I make? How pure is it? When organic chemistry students (~20 per year) run reactions to make new molecules, they need to know how successful they are. Chemical analyses of their reaction products reveal what they are, and sometimes also leftover reactants and byproducts.
  • For Forensic Science and Chemistry majors (~6-8 per year), GCMS is a centerpiece of the laboratory experience. They use it to determine whether a sample of blood plasma exceeded the legal ethanol percentage for drivers, and to identify residues of accelerants left on charred wood in a mock arson case.

Does teaching chemistry in the context of environmental issues that affect human health enhance learning? The majority of students (90% of students who responded to an end-of-the-semester survey for CHEM111) felt that relating chemistry concepts to environmental and health issues such as these enhanced their learning: lead in DC water, food and drug safety, climate change, and pollution in the Chesapeake Bay.

Impacts of this work go beyond air quality and chemistry. The students trained, all women and over 90% from underrepresented minorities, will enhance the diversity of the STEM work force. Findings have been shared in twelve presentations at national conferences.  The work is interdisciplinary, connected to the fields of Toxicology and of Environmental Justice. Finally, for the community, data collection has supported their fight for environmental justice, as highlighted in the local news. (https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/southwest-dc-is- getting-a-new-stadium-new-restaurants-and-more-dust-and-pollution-for-its-poorest-residents/2018/05 /05/19f4a0a4-4fb4-11e8-84a0-458a1aa9ac0a_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.ae494bb57a7d).
